review_title: Confused and directionless, product roadmaps a muddle

cons:
IBM has an absence of a meaningful cloud strategy combine with neglect of core infrastructure products. 
Way too many levels of management, trying to justify their positions by micro-management leading to stagnation.
Confused sales teams that are constantly re-organised so that IBM sellers always looking for the easiest quickest deal without any long-term strategy. Constant re-branding of the same-old products to inject new-life while minimising investment. 
Generally low morale as staff realise IBM is on a race to the bottom.

review_title: A great place to learn and develop.
pros:
- A virtually endless amount of technical and business resources to learn from,
- still by far the most interesting Research department in the industry,
- you will have the chance to work with some of the greatest minds in the IT sector (& not only),
- massive exposure on a wide range of technologies & markets,
- great culture, mentoring and advancement opportunities.
cons:
- Like in every other aspect of life, seniority & experience comes at a cost. Usually at the expense of slower reflexes and amount of time required to implement changes,
- as a consequence, it needs to catch up on a number of technologies that competition went faster into: cloud is a typical example,
- interdepartmental antagonisms exist, as one would expect in a company that offers a range of solutions that usually compete each other.

review_title: You’ll meet your best friends hear (but you’ll bond over complaining)
pros: People don’t take anything too seriously. Too big to fail (fully). Great work life balance. Fun people. Occasional travel to a massive conference. Name recognition. Good design culture. Always someone to learn from (either to aspire to be or vow NOT to be). They’ll pay you to learn. Individual teams have a lot of variety/variability and easy to switch. Decent efforts toward diversity and inclusion.
cons: Badly run business (product managers never produced a clear list of priorities in 9 years), old technology or architecture on all products and not enough engineers to fix it, low commitment to UX quality by business, overemphasis on time in band and not merit, managers barely have budget for raises or any team events, slight “boys club” but getting better, lots of politics, hard to hire and retain talent.

review_title: Incredible people, supportive teams, and amazing learning opportunities!
pros: Really great experiences from day one, IBM provides a LOT of opportunities for personal and professional growth. With really supportive people all around you to help you develop and grow, learning and personal development is emphasised in the company and there are aspects that make it feel more like a startup than a large and established corporation - which is fantastic as you feel positive about the company's development and future outlook. Everyone wants to see you succeed and that's an awesome community and culture to be a part of, regardless of background or previous experiences. The learning platforms and educational opportunities provided by IBM are also world-class, everything from short courses to certifications that will support your long-term career trajectory. Overall, it's been an incredible experience from day one.
cons: Lots of opportunities for learning and growth can make it daunting at times to know what to aim for - good thing is managers and other senior IBMers are more than happy to help you find clarity regarding learning and career development.

review_title: A great company requiring a cultural change
pros:
IBM is huge and so you set your own limits. I've been able to travel around the world, learn from the best and definitely I'm a much better professional than when I started.
People is great. At IBM personal relationships are valued and you can feel that. I've made real friends all around the world. The work environment is more than friendly.
cons:
There is a culture of setting unrealistics objectives, and afterwards twisting data or metrics to make it appear as everything went good. It is many times frustrating to work when the KPI are more important than reality itself.
Generally speaking, there is a lot of makeup and not much content.

review_title: IBM is a special place to work
pros:
IBM is a workplace, where you can intuitively develop yourself, in terms of technology, products and sales skills.
The culture at IBM enables you to socialize and build a sustainable network.
cons:
Internal meetings, which dramatically reduced in the meantime, keeps us busy. I would rather use this time to explore the market more.
Procedures are highly important, that keep us safe and I do believe they are necessary though, some things might get easier.

review_title: Avoid IBM if you want to grow
job_title: Senior Content Marketing Manager in New York, NY
pros: Strong health benefits with higher than expected family coverage levels, multiple options inside the plan. Broad investment choices inside the 401k. You'll likely work -with- some very nice people.
cons: This is a company stuck in the past, rewarding the people who mismanaged the company into modern irrelevance. There is very little modern about IBM, it is a business looking for a purpose in the digital world both from a product line up and marketing organization. No IBM product is first in its class. Marketing is slowly trying to catch up with modern times but is counting on veterans who never worked anywhere else in the last 20 years. Staff is constantly and randomly being reduced with groups of hundreds and sometimes thousands losing jobs at once. Chronic under-performers stay while the wrong people get let go. Bonuses are unheard of. The technology you will work with from Email to biz organization is the very best 1992 had to offer, maybe. Even if you come in with world-beating expertise and experience, there is some dimwitted executive above you with far less skill and far more political power who will never let you rise. There is no career growth for mid-career people.

review_title: You can be an asset too!
pros: One of the main reasons I'm still happily working in IBM is the flexibility privilege that we have here. As a working mother of 4 kids, I would definitely say that IBM is one of the best organizations that you could ask for. Work Life Balance is something that IBM care and keep encouraging us. The diversity and inclusion practice is also contributing to my sustainability in IBM. The learning and upskilling opportunities that IBM gives us is laudable and with the encouragement from our leaders and peers here, I'm definitely one of the constant learner and gaining valuable knowledge and upskilling myself in the preparation for my future roles.
cons: If anyone ask me, what would be the downside of IBM 10 years ago, I would say there are many but right now, I'm at the stage where I could see most of the gaps that I see in IBM is being filled in and we just need to keep up with the constant improvement that we are doing now.

job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
I joined IBM in 1988. Been here 34 years.
I came out as gay to my hiring manager and (in 1988!) he was delighted to tell me all about IBM's respect for diversity and protections for various minorities.
Just in the last five years, I got an adult diagnosis of autism (mild, with apparently excellent coping mechanisms). I get a lot of support from my management team and my peers, they are happy to let me work the hours that work best for me, and are always pointing me to resources for neurodiverse people, inviting me to take advantage of other accommodation opportunities.

I just wish I wasn't getting old, because I'd love to keep working for IBM for another 34 years.
cons: Twice during my long career, I spent some time in job positions that were not a great fit for my signature skills, and that was a bit depressing, but the job that followed each suboptimal experience was the best job to date!

review_title: Do not get deceived by the IBM's brand name !
pros: IBM brand name and policies but I guess you can not enjoy them much anyway if you are joining IBM GBS or CIC
cons:
I have recently joined in IBM by ignoring better offers from other companies just because of its brand value and just after a month or less I started regretting my decision deeply. 
I am having almost 6 years of experience in considerably trending technologies and frameworks in web application development and I was interviewed on the same as I mentioned in my resume. Finally when I joined IBM GBS, I got pulled into a project that works on old and completely different technologies and framework with respect to my experience. 
I also had to compromise with the project account, its infrastructure, timings and poor work life balance. I never expected that I will have such a bad experience with IBM.
I already informed to my manager that I am not happy with the project a couple of times but I got no help. If I adopt myself to my current project my experience will not have any meaning. So I am not able to get interest.
If you have motivation you can start any work but if you are not having interest in it, you simply cannot continue.
My suggestion, know the project thoroughly before you are pulled into it.

pros:
IBM allows you as many paths as you can imagine. You can start technical, transition to management, transition back, take options as they fit your needs and career goals. IBM will give you as many challenges as you can handle - and reward your successes. 
IBM is fiercely diverse. Different viewpoints are at every desk and this multi-party collaboration gives the company a strength and a staying power rarely found. You WILL find every political stripe, every community, every kind of person - but almost always friendly, professional, welcoming.
IBM is stable - in a tumultuous industry with much churn, you can find a home here.
cons: IBM is definitely a large company. You truly do own your career path, which means that if you end up in a situation where you need a change, you do need to speak up and take action. Once you do that, every manager and leadership team I've worked with has been open - focused on your happiness and productivity.

job_title: SAP Consultant in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: They really do invest in your learning. You do get constant opportunities for certifications and experience based learning. You do get random cash awards throughout the year and the health benefits are great.
cons:
My cons are specific to the Baton Rouge CIC, as I have come to find that colleagues at different locations with the same experience level as myself, with the same education and job role specialty have significantly higher salaries than mine. So much higher, that cost of living is definitely not the root of the difference.

Also, almost everything marketed to me when starting this job has been highly exaggerated. I was told to relocate in the middle of a pandemic and then sent to work from home for the next year. We're allowed to work in the office now but its not as nice as it was advertised. You have to provide your own second monitor, even in the office. When travelling, the per diems are outdated and barely cover the daily costs after pandemic inflation. They were NOT open to salary negotiation when accepting my offer. Also, the "opportunities" to get certifications are performance metrics but you are forced to use personal time to complete them.

review_title: You take the rough with the smooth
pros:
Good salary, interesting customers and work, exceptional peers. (For me at least). 

It will depend where you are, 'IBM' - particularly in the product side - is not one company, but a collection of small companies, this is good, it allows that product the flexibility to operate as is own entity.
cons:
Highly unstable environment, every few years they will without warning just axe about 20%- seemingly just to keep everyone on their toes. This is usually sales and tech sales - lab services (where I was) are rarely touched). 

Massively bureaucratic - it needs to be, it's a lot of people, but if that's the kind of thing that bothers you, think twice.

They make a big deal about there being amazing growth opportunities, but the reality is that if you are good at a job, you will stay there or get promoted into a management position, where you will stay. If you are not good, it's entirely possible to hide, which isn't great. Almost everyone knows someone who adds no value, shirks responsibility and just collects a paycheck

review_title: Good to work in IBM with Flexible timings
pros:
IBM provides unlimited WFH that is actually good. But do not get over-exicited reading this! Even this can depend on your manager ;)
Working in b-shifts and c-shifts are less
Women are provided cabs from 7 pm onwards to reach home safely if you get approval from your project to bear the cost
IBM provides unlimited sick leaves which no other organization has
There is no stringent 9 hours work policy. No swipe-in and out policy to record your working hours. Complete your work with no defects and you are good to go :)
cons:
IBM is not recommended if you are joining as a fresher. The opportunity to grow within the organization being a fresher and working at the most lower band is minimal. Exceptions can happen - ‘You are lucky if you get a good lead and manager’
You don’t get any perks for your hardwork. Poor pay package, almost no onsite for band 6
The company policies (for hike,onsite,band progression) are not very transparent and no scope to contact your HR. Your only hope is your People Manager. Your future in IBM is in the hands of your manager

review_title: Good first job. Overall not a great experience.
job_title: Applications Development Specialist in Baton Rouge, LA
pros:
Great place to network and meet like minded individuals.
Good place to gain insight into the business side of software contract work.
Good position to add to your resume.
cons:
I can break down the cons of my experience at IBM CIC Baton Rouge into 3 categories: 1. Pay 2. Management. 3. Projects 

1. The pay at the Baton Rouge CIC is low comparatively and relatively. I personally worked there for ~3 years, and was still earning under $50k annually as a developer. 

 2. Management is out of touch with the developers. When things don’t go as planned, management fails to take ownership over developers. Overall, management doesn’t care about developers. They only seem to care about developers charging hours to a project so they meet their numbers. These, among other, managerial issues are deeply rooted in the CIC. I have seen similar issues brought up to upper management, and sadly, little or nothing is done to address the issue's root cause. Instead management’s usual solution is to throw the CIC a pizza party or send you cookies to show you that they “care”.

3. I worked on 6 different projects while at the CIC, and only 2 of the 6 were quality. One of the “projects” I was assigned was for RI Dept of Health working as a call center operator scheduling covid tests for kids and teachers. Overall quality of projects is not great.

review_title: Hard to Stand Out, but Great Company Culture
job_title: Digital Marketing Intern in Austin, TX
pros: In my experience as an intern, IBM had a great company culture that really allowed for work-life balance and encouraged collaboration. It also did a great job at inviting and making interns feel welcome to connect with IBMers in a personal way. The internship program was very supportive and not high pressure or competitive, which was really nice and made it very easy to feel enthusiastic about – and focus on – the work I was doing. Their internships pay well compared to other previous internships I did, and overall I had a great internship experience.
cons:
One of the downsides about interning at IBM (which I think is probably the same for most companies of its size) is that it's so large, that it's hard to really standout and get exposure. 

First of all, I believe there were 80+ marketing interns in the program (or some large number around that, I can't remember exactly). Interns were put into teams of 3-4, and each team was tasked with a specific project for the summer, across a variety of different marketing functions. The teams were assigned project managers, who were great and engaged, but the size of the program meant that it was really hard to get and exposure.

Connecting with higher-level IBMers (or IBMers in other areas of marketing) was also challenging at times because it doesn't occur naturally through the work you do, which means that it often depends on whether or not they have time to meet with you whenever you reach out.

[NOTE: My internship was during a time when everything was still entirely virtual, so it's possible that these cons are a result of that. If they go back to in-person internships at some point, then it's possible that these challenges might not me as prominent.]

pros:
Good benefits

cons:
Zero job security
DO NOT RECOMMEND FOR COLLEGE GRADS
Some new hires are assigned SAP practice and it's very hard to get out of (SAP incredibly dry and pays less than other roles) New hires have no choice over their starting assignment.... at least when I joined

pros: Lots of opportunities to work on different cool things. IBM doesn't stick you in a little box - if you've got interest in different areas, they'll work with you to make it happen. It's easy to get exposure to cutting-edge work, even if you don't yet have the background for it. Fairly chill about different working styles and accommodations - if you need to leave for a bit to pick up your kids or run an errand, that's fine, as long as you're still responsive and ultimately getting your work done. Respectful of time off.
cons:
Salaries are somewhat under-market. IBM also relies on a lot of custom internal tooling and somewhat dated infrastructure. They're in the process of updating their infrastructure, but the custom tooling is both a benefit and a drawback - in chip development it's a source of competitive advantage, but it also provides less transferable skillsets if you later leave the company. The larger tools are generally well-documented, but for the smaller ones your mileage may vary.

Teams are also rather lean, but this is improving as IBM has recently started hiring again.

- IBM offers free courses from e-learning websites like Udemy, Coursera, Orelly and so on.
- You can also opt for claiming your internet bills as per WFH option.
cons: I don't think I have any cons at this moment as everything is going well. pros:

pros: A formidable training ground as there is aridiculous amount of traininng options through internal platforms and lots of potential coaches very open to share their expertise. Great cross cultural exchange as you work with people from literllaly all over the world. Very good benefits plan.
cons:
A bit too bureaucratic for my taste. Focus is not truly on performance but mostly on measurements and reaching specific indicators for the area. Changing roles is quite a challenge and there is a lot of push back from the business unit to let go of a practitioner to another area (two examples: one person had to negotiate for over 1 year and essentially stop doing her job to be allowed to move to another role, another made 3 attempts where she was told that there was no problem with moving, but had to wait 6 months to do so). 
Locally, management still needs development; in my personal experience, feedback from management was, with 2 exceptions (noting that I reported to 6 different managers in a little over a year), simplistic, sometimes recycled and never clear on which gaps needed improvement to further advance your career. Managers in general tend to be too nice and try to avoid making you feel bad rather than challenging you to become a better professional.

review_title: Life at IBM as a Software Engineer
job_title: Software Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
- Amazing Management. Extremely kind and flexible to your external schedule. Meetings with 1st line manager don't feel like interrogations, but like casual conversations where you chat about work and some common interests. Speaking with an executive feels the same as casually chatting with a coworker.

- Great culture. People go out of their way to help you if you ask. There is no "cut throat" attitude, everyone works together as part of a team and supports each other when needed. 

- Tons of great communities full of people who share similar passions. Great places to connect with other IBMers from around the world who share the same interests (hobbies, crafts, etc) as you do. 

- Good pay; Competitive, and above average. 

- Lots of opportunities and incentives to work on skills that lead to promotion.
cons:
- Depending on your team, you may have meetings either very early in the morning or very late in the day. This is due to the global nature of some teams.

- Dental Benefits could be better. Little coverage for 'major' surgeries.

- Requirements for moving up the band system are defined too broadly. For example, there are docs and even badges for "Software Engineer" career paths, but there is no distinction between Cloud engineers and Z (Mainframe) engineers, even though the type and scope of work is vastly different between them.
